channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: An Elon Musk-backed political group is posting fake Kamala Harris ads on Facebook
item.description: Ads seemingly advocating for Vice President Kamala Harris on Facebook are really part of an effort by a dark money group to mislead voters. The messages have been viewed millions of times.
item.content:encoded:
Ads seemingly advocating for Vice President Kamala Harris on Facebook are really part of an effort by a dark money group to mislead voters. The messages have been viewed millions of times.

(Image credit: Progress 2028 via Meta's Ad Library/screenshotted by NPR)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: Harris will spend election night at Howard University, the HBCU that helped shape her
item.description: Harris is the first vice president to be an alum of a historically Black college, and if she wins, would make history as the first president to be an HBCU graduate.
item.content:encoded:
Harris is the first vice president to be an alum of a historically Black college, and if she wins, would make history as the first president to be an HBCU graduate.

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski)
item.dc:creator: Deepa Shivaram

item.title: Bird flu has been found in a pig for the first time in the U.S.
item.description: The discovery of an infected pig at a backyard farm in Oregon raises concerns about bird flu's potential to become a human threat.
item.content:encoded:
The discovery of an infected pig at a backyard farm in Oregon raises concerns about bird flu's potential to become a human threat.

(Image credit: Cynthia Goldsmith, Jackie Katz)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: ‘Witches marks’ and curses found carved into the walls of historic England manor
item.description: About 20 carvings in “a wide range of designs” including some meant to trap demons or to seek help from the Virgin Mary have been found at Gainsborough Old Hall in Lincolnshire, England.
item.content:encoded: About 20 carvings in “a wide range of designs” including some meant to trap demons or to seek help from the Virgin Mary have been found at Gainsborough Old Hall in Lincolnshire, England.
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Enforcement was considered discriminatory. Now New Yorkers can jaywalk legally
item.description: The NYPD can no longer ticket jaywalkers, after years of protest that enforcement unfairly targeted Black and Hispanic New Yorkers.
item.content:encoded:
The NYPD can no longer ticket jaywalkers, after years of protest that enforcement unfairly targeted Black and Hispanic New Yorkers.

(Image credit: Charly Triballeau)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: What could happen at the Supreme Court under Harris and Trump
item.description: Depending on who wins the presidential election and the Senate, the conservative supermajority could remain the same, be trimmed or expand to an even larger and more lopsided conservative majority.
item.content:encoded:
Depending on who wins the presidential election and the Senate, the conservative supermajority could remain the same, be trimmed or expand to an even larger and more lopsided conservative majority.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: The World's Largest River is Running Low
item.description: The region drained by the Amazon River, including the Amazon Rainforest, is in the second year of a punishing drought. That has lead to the lowest water levels in more than 100 years for the Amazon and its major tributaries. Millions of people and an array of wildlife depend on those quickly disappearing waters. We travel to the region to see the effects.
item.content:encoded: The region drained by the Amazon River, including the Amazon Rainforest, is in the second year of a punishing drought. That has lead to the lowest water levels in more than 100 years for the Amazon and its major tributaries. Millions of people and an array of wildlife depend on those quickly disappearing waters. We travel to the region to see the effects.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: The U.S. economy is growing solidly. Here's what's working — and what's not
item.description: The U.S. economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8% in the third quarter, led by strong consumer spending. The news comes days before a presidential election in which the economy has been top of mind for many voters.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. economy grew at an annual rate of 2.8% in the third quarter, led by strong consumer spending. The news comes days before a presidential election in which the economy has been top of mind for many voters.

(Image credit: Spencer Platt)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Worried about your 2024 ballot being counted? These states let you track it online
item.description: “There's no need to panic,” an elections expert tells NPR. All but three states have free tracking sites that send updates to voters as their ballot goes through the system.
item.content:encoded:
“There's no need to panic,” an elections expert tells NPR. All but three states have free tracking sites that send updates to voters as their ballot goes through the system.

(Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: Handsy fans disrupted a World Series game. Here are 5 notable MLB interference cases
item.description: Two Yankees fans were ejected from Game 4 of the World Series for trying to pry a ball out of a Dodgers player’s glove. It's a particularly brazen instance of fan interference, but far from the first.
item.content:encoded:
Two Yankees fans were ejected from Game 4 of the World Series for trying to pry a ball out of a Dodgers player’s glove. It's a particularly brazen instance of fan interference, but far from the first.

(Image credit: Al Bello)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Treisman
